abstract: <jats:p>A major concern for all copy number variation (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">CNV</jats:styled-content>) detection algorithms is their reliability and repeatability. However, it is difficult to evaluate the reliability of <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">CNV</jats:styled-content>‐calling strategies due to the lack of gold‐standard data that would tell us which <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">CNV</jats:styled-content>s are real. We propose that if <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">CNV</jats:styled-content>s are called in duplicate samples, or inherited from parent to child, then these can be considered validated <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">CNV</jats:styled-content>s. We used two large family‐based genome‐wide association study (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">GWAS</jats:styled-content>) datasets from the <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">GENEVA</jats:styled-content> consortium to look at concordance rates of <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">CNV</jats:styled-content> calls between duplicate samples, parent‐child pairs, and unrelated pairs. Our goal was to make recommendations for ways to filter and use <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">CNV</jats:styled-content> calls in <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">GWAS</jats:styled-content> datasets that do not include family data. We used <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">P</jats:styled-content>enn<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">CNV</jats:styled-content> as our primary <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">CNV</jats:styled-content>‐calling algorithm, and tested <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">CNV</jats:styled-content> calls using different datasets and marker sets, and with various filters on <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">CNV</jats:styled-content>s and samples. Using the Illumina core <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">H</jats:styled-content>uman<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">H</jats:styled-content>ap550 single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) set, we saw duplicate concordance rates of approximately 55% and parent‐child transmission rates of approximately 28% in our datasets. <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">GC</jats:styled-content> model adjustment and sample quality filtering had little effect on these reliability measures. Stratification on <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">CNV</jats:styled-content> size and <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">DNA</jats:styled-content> sample type did have some effect. Overall, our results show that it is probably not possible to find a <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">CNV</jats:styled-content>‐calling strategy (including filtering and algorithm) that will give us a set of “reliable” <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">CNV</jats:styled-content> calls using current chip technologies. But if we understand the error process, we can still use <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">CNV</jats:styled-content> calls appropriately in genetic association studies.</jats:p>

title: Using Family Data as a Verification Standard to Evaluate Copy Number Variation Calling Strategies for Genetic Association Studies
